segments.text: Talking about staff assistants now.
And this all dawned on me with Kent Caperton.
And he represented the student body at a graduation ceremony and did such a super job.
He was better than anybody on that stage that day.
Because among those first were Caperton, Miller, and Dave Mayfield.
Yeah.
Among those first student assistants.
And Kent was the first one.
Well, I think that was a very good idea.
And it helped us immeasurably in certain areas, Kent in particular, and then Roger Miller too, and others that followed.
But as a result of that kind of togetherness, we formed, we, Harry Green, and Peggy Cooper, and me, and Kent,
and Roger and sometimes John Sharp established the Fine Guys Association, which we referred to as the FGA.
And our main mission was to get together at somebody's home for Monday night football.
And we would down quite a few beers and refreshments, food and so forth.
and become very close friends.
And it was called the FGA.
And Gint and Roger were charter members.
And we teased John Sharp and played like he wasn't really a full-fledged member.
And he really got upset with us because we'd let him come to the FGA meetings, but we weren't really sure enough to make him a charter member.
But we had a lot of good times there.
And in our own little world, a closeness that I've never seen duplicated.
I don't think those kind of things are happening now.
I fear they're not.
How easy was it for you to be completely candid in answering a question to either of these two men?
I had no qualms about that at all.
reported on things that I had seen or heard that I would not say to you today right now because I thought it was that important.

Some of them that were really... And you learned by experience that they were not going to hold it against you if you said what the truth was, even though you knew they weren't going to enjoy that truth.
That's true.
I had no qualms at all about saying, look, this is not good news that I'm about to tell you, but you really need to know this.
And I told them collectively things that I wouldn't have told my mother.
Who would Williams, on his administrative staff, whom do you think Williams trusted most or turned to most, relied upon most?
Calhoun.
Why were they so compatible?
I think they had comparable racehorse minds down the same
And I think totally trusted each other.
I never did hear Dr. Williams express any kind of disappointment or criticism.
That whole operation over there.
And he...
He wanted to change.
He called me in one day.
He says, Edwin, what would happen?
And this is how he would pay attention to detail.
What would happen if we stopped blowing that damn whistle at the laundry at 8, 12, and 5, or was it 8, 12, 1, and 5?
It may have been four times a day.
And I thought for a minute, and I said, Dr. Williams, there'll be some questions about it.
but I don't think this university is going to collapse.
He said, call them and tell them to stop blowing that damn thing today.
And I don't remember who it was.
I think it was Parsons, I guess.
Or maybe it was Vestal, auxiliary services, the laundry.
The whistle was at the laundry.
And whoever it was says, my God, are you kidding?
I said, I tell you what.
I don't want to be around here if that thing blows again today.
And so the whistle went out.
But he was so funny about little details that somehow were offensive to him or unnecessary.
And the worst excuse was, well, we've always done it this way.
He did not buy that at all.
Now, I came to the impression that one of the many talents Dr. Williams had

was that at Clemson, a separate land grant school in the southern state, which was once all male, all white, compulsory military, not located on the main highway, about 100 miles from the capital city where the state university was located in that state, that Clemson had gone through many of the same changes, while he was a faculty member and administrator there, that A&M had gone through.
So he could rely upon the experience there.
He could understand some of that.
Let's see, athletics.
Share any athletic recollections for both presidents and their relations that you recall.
Mr.
Rudder was dead level serious about it and football in particular.
I never heard him say anything about basketball, baseball, track.
He just was a fiend about football and wanted to whip everybody's butts.
Now that's all there are to it, including Admiral McCall's Bears.
I remember that before the Cotton Bowl, when we were going to play Bear Bryant, I was 68.
He did something I'd never dreamed I would ever see, and that is he, the president, in his big old gray suit went down there and gave a pep talk
to Gene Stallings.
He could not say Stallings.
It was Stallings and his boys and gave them a pep talk with tears in his eyes about going out and beating hell out of Alabama, which they did.
And I was at the game with him, the four of us, and he was so emotional about it that he said, come with me.
And we went down and got on the cotton bowl field somehow and went down to the dressing room and he gave them another speech and they're standing stark naked.
And I told the boy that was on that team out at Eldorado, a banker not five years ago, Bob Sykes says, have you ever heard of, I can't remember his name, I said, yeah.
He was on the cotton bowl, the...
He said, yeah, he sure was.
He took me to the bank at El Dorado, and he introduced me, and I said, well, Charlie, I said, the last time I saw you, you were starting against these watchmen.
And then I explained.
But the Olympic Games came up, and Randy Mattson was going down, and Mr. Rutter came to me about six weeks before, maybe two months, and he says, Edwin, I'm going to buy your way
to the Olympic Games, you and Peggy.
And you're going with me and Henry Clay and Maggie McGee and Sally.
And it's not going to cost you one penny, except that I want you to get the tickets to all of the events that we want to go to.
And you make the arrangements for us to stay in a private home in Mexico City and get us a driver where all of us can get in one Cadillac and remember
Mr. Clay's quite a large man.
We need a big car.
And he said, if you will make all the arrangements where all we have to do is go and pay for it, you got a trip.
I said, you got it, David.
And we got a house with maids and servants for the man that was in the executive for Kodak International, South America, Mexico, Central and South America.
He was a judge in the sailing Olympics.
turned his house over to us.
And we had a chauffeur with an old Cadillac that hauled us all over Mexico City.
We went to the track and field.
We saw Randy throw the shot and get the gold medal.
And it was another example of how Mr. Rutter would go to any ends to further the school in this way through recognition of athletics.
But mainly his love was for football.
I told you what he said to Shelby about his, he said, you're going to get the same contract I get, nothing.
But Jack Williams.
considered going to the games, I think, another necessary responsibility.
I think it bored into tears.
There was another tough, long work day.
That's right.
And if things didn't go right, it was another tough encounter with the regents who spent some time.
Dooley Bell was just, I mean, I've seen him on,
field trips with his Walkman radio on, listening to the TU game.
Not A&M, but he wanted to know who was hopefully beating them at the moment.
And he was quite serious about it.
And I had one picture here I wanted to share with you.
There's one of them.
I can't help but figure that was the day he was inaugurated.
I can't remember why we were all there.
There's his wife.
It must be the day that he was sworn in as a regent.
I think so.
Oh boy.
I was so nervous as they were coming out.
And I had a little land camera.
And Mr.
Rudder said, I'm going to shake his hand, get a picture of me.
And I was so nervous I had to put the camera on the metal rail to take this picture.
But that was a big event.
But Williams realized that athletics and football in particular was a flagpole to rally the alumni around.
and played like he enjoyed it, but he really didn't.
Now, we didn't have under either of them, we didn't have any athletic scandals that I can recall.
No alleged cheating.
Not that I remember.
We had some coaches that were terminated and some new coaches coming and going.
Ballard came in.
Right.
Stallings out and Ballard in under Dr. Williams.
Right.
And as I have heard the unverified story that he turned Bud Wilkinson, the former great coach at OU, as a kind of advisor as to who to hire.
That supposedly.
If he did that, I don't remember it.
Somebody told me that it was Wilkinson that suggested Ballard would be a real good choice.
I remember coming into the.

office one morning and that was one of the times he was there early and the Lord was there lighting his pipe and Dr. Williams evidently it all had been worked out and he said Edmund that's our new football coach you might want to go meet him but that was just something that had that he had to go through but Rutter was you know he was a coach too yes football coach and that's where he and Miss Rutter met
He was the coach at Brady High School.
She was a teacher.
Oh, really?
I didn't know that.
She thought he was the handsomest thing she'd ever seen.
And they fell in love and married.
Now, she was from Brady?
She was born in Sonora, Texas.
Went to school close to her family's ranch, which is on an old road between downtown London
and the town of Hext.
Hext is on Highway 29 West and London is on the road that connects Mason with Junction.
And she went to school usually horseback and the principal of the school's main thrill in life was catching she and whoever rode with her coming into town on their horses
and driving by his car and slamming his hand on the side of the car to make the horses pitch them off.
And then she went to UT and made lots of contacts there.
Now, somebody told me one day that she and John and Nellie Connolly were undergraduate friends.
I think that's right.
Is that right?
OK. And the Pickles somehow came in there, Jake Pickles.
They were real close with Jake Pickles.
That wouldn't hurt.
Yeah.
That wouldn't hurt.
Then I heard also two or three people who told me about Mr.
Rudder and a heifer at Tarleton that he staked on the football field.
That is the story.
And that's where I have it mixed up.
It was at Tarleton, not at A&M.
Somehow I had it in my mind that you're right, it was Tarleton.
And somebody told me that they asked him,
what happened if the heifer didn't produce as much milk as you needed to sell that day.
And then he said, well, heck, you just add water on those days.
Yeah, that's the story.
I got it mixed up on where it was.
And as I understand, the way it began is that he told the coach that he didn't have enough money and he was going to drop out and go home and go to work, depression time.
And that the coach talked to somebody and they came up with the animal.
And the coach said, okay, we can let it graze on the football field.
All right, let's see.
Were both of these families Methodist?
The Williams and the Rudders?
The Rudders for sure.
And I believe the Williams were too, but somehow that doesn't...
In no way do I infer that you needed to be a Methodist to be
a key person at A&M, but they were both church-going families.
They were both good parents.
Let's see, Williams had, what, an adopted daughter.
The one that was married in his house was an adopted child.
And then a natural daughter.
Yeah, yeah.
And then the Rudders.
They weren't there like the Rudder kids were.
I knew every one of them.
Now the Rudders were two boys and two girls?
Two boys and three girls.
Ann and Jane died, and then there's Bud and Bob.
I had Ann in my first summer class in 1960.

and she made a good solid grade with me because I had another faculty member's daughter in that same class and he was much discombobulated with me because his daughter had made a B and he told me she had never made a B at A&M Solid High School.
I told him this was not A&M Solid High School.
Then he blurted out the question, well, what grade did the old rudder girl make?
And I told him she made the same grade that his daughter made.
And he then cleared his face and said, well, OK, that's all right then.
Somebody apparently had told him that I had given Ann Rudder an A and his daughter a B.
And that had him very bothered.
Let's see, any other anecdotes, legends, myths about either of those men in those days?
A funny thing happened one night at one of these alumni gatherings, the board meetings.
Mr. Rutter went to them.
Faithfully, Dr. Williams would look for any kind of excuse and would send me.
But one night, one weekend rather, we met at Bandera, Texas.
And J. Harold Dunn, who was on that board, not the NM board,
took it upon himself to make all of the arrangements for our entertainment at the big dance hall up there that Saturday night.
Dick Winters did a barbecue for us.
And then we all retreated to downtown Bandera, had reserved seats.
And he had some of them's wives were there for some reason.
But for those whose wives were not there,
legitimate escort so everyone would have someone to dance with.
And the one I had was one of the Frost National Bank ladies whose husband had been killed in one of the wars.
But Harold Dunn made all of those arrangements and made sure that we had a good band there that night.
And I was seated next to Mr.
Rudder and
All of the sound suddenly stopped, and there were lights over the doorway so that as people entered, you could see them.
And a small group of five or six people came in, and there was the most beautiful human being I've ever seen in my life in a white silvery gown with sequins all over it, blonde-headed girl.
And I said to Mr.
Rudder, you see that girl there?
He says, whoo!
I said, I'll bet you before this night's over, I'll bet you $5 that she'll let me dance with her.
And he said, well, she's with somebody.
I said, I'll bet you $5 I'll dance with her.
He said, you're on.
And before they were seated, the music started, and I went up to that girl, said hello to her escort or whatever, and I said,
You are about the prettiest thing I've ever seen.
Would you dance with me right now before you all settle in?
She said, sure.
And so I steered her over to this long table.
There was Darcy McQuarrie and Earl Rudder and Harold Dunn and Maggie McGee, all those old boys.
And I could see Mr.
Rudder looking up at me as we were coming to him.
And as we walked by, he had his $5 out.
And I picked it up as I went by.
I told you the airplane story.
One time, Mr.
Rudder said, let's go dove hunting.
This was in, like, October.
I said, when do you want to go?
We'd gone over to the Herman Heath place in Austin, Buda, and other places.
And he said, I want to go to the ranch, his ranch.
It was really miserable.
It still is.
I said, when do you want to go?
And he said, Friday afternoon.
I said, well, how are you going to get to Lubbock to the game?
He says, I'm not going.
He said, I am just sick and tired of everything that's going on at these ballgames as much as I love them.
I need a break.
And I'm not going to the Lubbock game.
But I have to be out of town.
I said, sure, we'll go.
So we went and landed at Menard.
There's a little airstrip at Menard right by the Coatman Co-op.
And we landed there and went hunting.
And that night, he said, let's go down to London.
and eat a chicken fried steak at the cafe.
I said, let's do.
And the dance hall was right next door.
And they are still on Saturday nights dancing there.
And we were seated there.
And there was a one-inch wall made out of 1 by 12s between the dance hall and the cafe where we were seated.
I said, I think I heard the music start in there.
I think the dance has started.
And he put his hand up on the wall.
He said, no.
It's not throbbing enough.
The dance hadn't started.
I'll tell you when the dance starts.
But we just got there to escape.
And Mr. Rutter was much better, more skilled at breaking away from it all when he'd reached the saturation point.
than Dr. Williams was.
He could unwind pretty well for a while and then go back.
But Dr. Williams couldn't.
And again, I think both of their intensity with their job and lack of Williams would play like he was playing golf.
But his mind was still on him.
And I think that killed both of them.
Let's make believe that you are in a position to give advice
to the A&M board and campus leadership today?
What would it be for now and the future?
The A&M board and what?
And the campus leadership as well, the president, the provost, et cetera.
I think one thing I would advise, if I was in that high and mighty position, is to look at ways that we might
over a planned and graceful period of time reduce the enrollment.
I think it's way too high.
And in doing that in an organized way, get back to what both Williams and Rutter hoped for, and that is
personalize the classroom situation, get it down to reasonable numbers where they do know Professor Monroe and a little bit about him and vice versa.
And that the class sizes be reduced in particular areas to where it should be.
Student-teacher ratio is something that really bothers me.
And yet, in 1950, when I took

chemistry a sophomore level chemistry there were 333 students in that class but i think we're losing a lot of the closeness between students and faculty that we had at one time and uh i think as you had pointed out earlier with one example that we're with that we've broken down a great deal on our interest in counseling with students about courses to take
How do you compensate for a guy that's weak?
And I don't think we know them that well, like the poor boy that jumped off the building the other day.
I'm not sure anybody could have saved him.
But those kind of things are rearing up more and more.
And I think it all goes back to what Dr. Williams said.
You get above 35,000, and the place begins to break up.
And I think we've seen a lot of that.
The political part, namely the

Jesus himself, I don't know, might have to intervene, but to get the selection of board members back to something that's other than political and get people on these boards that understand higher education, that's critical.
And if the board and the administrators can't get along and can't agree because of politics, I think that's a sad state of affairs.
That one I don't know how you'll ever solve unless you have the right kind of governor in there.
Do today's former student association leadership and today's regents, are they people of lesser stature than 20, 30 years ago?
They seem to be.
Maybe with the former students, we're dealing with so much volume.
But you don't see, I don't see,
I see a lot of people in the key positions that I've never heard of before.
Like when I was talking to Dick Hervey.
He was rattling off who the key leaders were when he was the executive director.
And it was Jay Harold Dunn and Conley from... Dick Conley.
Dick Conley.
Dick Winters.
And he just started rattling off... John Younger.
Yeah, and they were all corporate presidents.
people that could have called the governor's office and gotten through quickly.
Today's leaders are good, decent people, but they are just middle class folks like the rest of us that don't have quite as much muscle as they might have had.
Those leaders, those caliber of people are bound to be out there.
But to me, they're just not coming forward to serve like they did at that time.
back in those days.
And the same thing with the region.
Somehow, regardless of what the system is, we're not getting the kind of people that come to campus and say, Mr. President, what do you want us to do to support you?
It's what I want you to do for me.
It may be contrary in all ways to the good of the university.
Let's see.
Did I ask you for favorite Williams anecdote?
Yeah.
Humor?
Yeah, we got some of those.
Okay.
I'm inclined to say let's quit for today.
And then we get into student.
Okay.
On another day, we'll do your student days.
That'd be fine.
Because it's 315, 320 now.
I'll start by saying that...
when I really hadn't thought seriously yet about coming to A&M.
My dad was such a rabid Aggie fan, having never been to college of any sort, though.
But he was so impressed by the men in San Marcos that had gone to A&M that he decided in his mind that that must be the best school in the world and wanted very much for me to go.
And the way he got me to go, and we'll start this next time, I went to him one day.
I said, Daddy, my trombone's worn out.
I can nearly see through the slide.
I'm playing football and I don't get to play at halftime anyway.
I think I'll just quit the band.
Boy, that was a knife in the heart for a professional musician.
He says, no, no, you're not going to quit the band.
Here's what I'll do, he said, about that old worn-out horn.
He said, if that's an embarrassment to you, I'm going to the San Antonio Music Company
and buy you a super old gold-colored trombone, the finest made.
And he said, that'll probably cost me $3 or $4 a week, but I'll pay for it that way if you promise me that you will play that trombone in the Aggie band.
I said, OK. And I didn't give it any more thought than that, and I did.
And after I was married halfway through school, the band was tough those first two years.
I can tell you, well, I will, horror stories.

But when I got married, living in Collegeview, I thought, now here's my chance to gracefully get out of this thing and have more free time and not all the misery that goes with the promptness required of somebody in the band.
And I've been in a hard field of study, and I need to study more.
So easy.
And then I thought, now wait just a minute.
I think he meant four years, not two.
And I'm not going to forget.
And I've always been proud that I did not when it would have been so easy.
I would say I didn't have a car and a bicycle.
And you still think he did mean to for four years?
I think so.
I know the spirit was there in that.
Had you visited the campus?
Only for a football game or two.
Not many of those.
We couldn't afford to.
I saw as many Aggie games in Austin as I did here because it's just 28 miles.
Now you came in 49?
So you were a freshman in college a year after me, so I can identify with those words.
And I was in the last freshman class to attend the Riverside campus.
The Riverside campus.
